simulated_ratings.title: They Shoot Horses, Don't They? (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bleak, riveting character study that left me wrung out in a good way.

simulated_ratings.title: 21 Up (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The longitudinal look at real lives and class feels quietly profound.

simulated_ratings.title: Ordinary People (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An intimate, unsparing family drama that hits hard but feels truthful.

simulated_ratings.title: Kids (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Raw and nihilistic in a way that felt more exploitative than illuminating for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Little Big Man (1970)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A witty, humane revisionist Western with heart and bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Fargo (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Darkly funny and painfully human crime tale with perfect understatement.

simulated_ratings.title: Jaws (1975)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense and iconic, though the blockbuster thrills matter less to me than the character beats.

simulated_ratings.title: Seven Up! (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Simple in form but fascinating as the seed of a life-spanning human portrait.

simulated_ratings.title: Midnight Cowboy (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, gritty friendship that lingers long after the credits.

simulated_ratings.title: Koyaanisqatsi (a.k.a. Koyaanisqatsi: Life Out of Balance) (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mesmerizing images and Glass’s score moved me, even if the detachment kept me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: 35 Up (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A deepening, empathetic mosaic of ordinary lives and choices.

simulated_ratings.title: TÁR (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A cool, absorbing character study of power and artistry that invites reflection.

simulated_ratings.title: 56 Up (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cumulative, humane and quietly devastating in its portrait of time.

simulated_ratings.title: 7 Plus Seven (1970)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Incremental but engaging, building the foundation for the series’ poignancy.

simulated_ratings.title: Umbrellas of Cherbourg, The (Parapluies de Cherbourg, Les) (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lush, bittersweet and formally daring in a way that swept me up.

simulated_ratings.title: Amadeus (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeously acted and staged, a rich meditation on envy and genius.

simulated_ratings.title: To Die For (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp, chilly satire with a magnetic lead and just the right sting.

simulated_ratings.title: Boogie Nights (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Expansive, empathetic and propulsive, with surprising heart beneath the excess.

simulated_ratings.title: Kramer vs. Kramer (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An intimate, compassionate drama that earns its emotion without schmaltz.

simulated_ratings.title: Planet of the Apes (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart and provocative, though the sci-fi trappings keep me a bit cooler.

simulated_ratings.title: Winnie the Pooh and the Blustery Day (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, whimsical comfort that still charms me.

simulated_ratings.title: Annie Hall (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wry, tender and observant about love’s neuroses.

simulated_ratings.title: What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? (1962)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deliciously macabre and psychologically sharp without relying on gore.

simulated_ratings.title: Terms of Endearment (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A funny-sad family drama that balances prickliness with genuine warmth.

simulated_ratings.title: A Plasticine Crow (1981)

simulated_ratings.title: Onibaba (1964)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmospheric, haunting and morally charged—a folk nightmare with weight.

simulated_ratings.title: Hud (1963)

simulated_ratings.title: Fly, The (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tragic and compelling, but the body horror sometimes overwhelms my enjoyment.

simulated_ratings.title: Open Water (2003)
